perturbation.original_text: 1. Confidential Information. Member shall not, during the term of the Franchise Agreement or thereafter, communicate, divulge or use, for any purpose other than the operation of the Franchised Business, any confidential information, knowledge, trade secrets or know-how which may be communicated to Member or which Member may learn by virtue of Member's relationship with Franchisee. All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System ("Confidential Information") is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member's attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member; or which, at the time of the disclosure to Member, had become a part of the public domain.
perturbation.changed_text: 1. Confidential Information. Member shall not, during the term of the Franchise Agreement or thereafter, communicate, divulge or use, for any purpose other than the operation of the Franchised Business, any confidential information, knowledge, trade secrets or know-how which may be communicated to Member or which Member may learn by virtue of Member's relationship with Franchisee. All information, knowledge and know-how relating to Franchisor, its business plans, Franchised Businesses, or the System ("Confidential Information") is deemed confidential, except for information that Member can demonstrate came to Member's attention by lawful means prior to disclosure to Member. Information that is generally known within the specific restaurant industry is also exempt from this definition of Confidential Information.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces an ambiguity to the definition of 'Confidential Information.' Originally, the definition only excluded information already in the public domain or previously known to the Member. By adding 'Information that is generally known within the specific restaurant industry is also exempt from this definition of Confidential Information,' it broadens the exception. This contradicts the latter part of the original definition, because something can be in the restaurant industry and still not be considered public domain. The definition provided in the last part of the section is now being conflicted.

perturbation.original_text: 2. Covenants Not to Compete. (a) Member specifically acknowledges that, pursuant to the Franchise Agreement, and by virtue of its position with Franchisee, Member will receive valuable specialized training and Confidential Information, including, without limitation, information regarding the operational, sales, promotional, and marketing methods and techniques of Franchisor and the System. (b) Member covenants and agrees that during the term of the Franchise Agreement, except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, for itself, or through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any person, persons, partnership, corporation, or entity: (i) Own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, rent or lease to, or have any other interest in business that (directly or indirectly) operates, or grants franchises or licenses to operate, a restaurant featuring pizza and related food specialties or that offers products or services substantially similar to those then offered by Pizza Fusions Restaurants ("Competitive Business"); C - 1 Source: PF HOSPITALITY GROUP INC., 10-12G, 9/23/2015 (ii) Divert or attempt to divert any business or customer, or potential business or customer, to any Competitive Business; or (iii) Induce any person to leave his or her employment with Franchisee or Franchisor. (c) Member covenants and agrees that during the Post-Term Period (defined below), except as otherwise approved in writing by Franchisor, Member shall not, either directly or indirectly, own, manage, engage in, be employed by, advise, make loans to, consult for, or have any other interest in any Competitive Business that is, or intends to operate, within a three (3) mile radius of the premises of your Franchised Business or within a three (3) mile radius of any Franchised Business then-operating or under construction to operate under the System. (d) As used in this Agreement, the term "Post-Term Period" shall mean a continuous uninterrupted period of two (2) years from the date of: (a) a transfer permitted under Section 14 of the Franchise Agreement; (b) expiration or termination of the Franchise Agreement (regardless of the cause for termination); (c) termination of Member's employment with Franchisee; and/or (d) a final order of a duly authorized arbitrator, panel of arbitrators, or a court of competent jurisdiction (after all appeals have been taken) with respect to any of the foregoing or with respect to the enforcement of this Agreement; either directly or indirectly (through, on behalf of, or in conjunction with any persons, partnership, corporation or entity).

perturbation.explanation: By changing 'will receive' to 'may receive', it introduces an internal contradiction because in all of Section 2, the contract treats receiving 'valuable specialized training and Confidential Information' as a given, a necessary condition for the restrictions that follow. If the member 'may receive' it, the subsequent restrictions in 2(b) and 2(c) become less enforceable because they are predicated on something that is no longer certain. This now contradicts the member covenants in the later part of section 2, since it may be argued that the member did not receive Confidential Information. This makes the covenants not to compete less enforceable because they are tied to the Member actually receiving Confidential Information.

perturbation.original_text: 3. Injunctive Relief. Member acknowledges that any failure to comply with the requirements of this Agreement will cause Franchisor irreparable injury, and Member agrees to pay all court costs and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by Franchisor in obtaining specific performance of, or an injunction against violation of, the requirements of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 3. Injunctive Relief. Member acknowledges that any failure to comply with *certain* requirements of this Agreement *may* cause Franchisor irreparable injury, and Member agrees to pay all court costs and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by Franchisor in obtaining specific performance of, or an injunction against violation of, the requirements of this Agreement. *However, this will be determined on a case-by-case basis.*
perturbation.explanation: The original text says that a failure to comply, will definitely result in irreparable injury. Changing this to 'may' cause irreparable injury and the addition of 'However, this will be determined on a case-by-case basis' creates a contradiction. The clause now implies uncertainty regarding the consequences of non-compliance, which weakens the enforceability of the entire agreement. This directly contradicts the initial acknowledgment that non-compliance will cause irreparable harm. This would contradict the Injunctive Relief, weakening its statement of how it cause irreparable injury to Franchisor.
